sp.p: I have not taken any, I do not know what to do; what would you adviſe me to?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: I adviſe you to? Nay, you are in the right to make it a Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: He ſays he'll ſettle all his Eſtate upon him too.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: O take it, take it, to be ſure, it's the fitteſt Match in the World, you cant't do a wiſer Thing certainly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: 'Twill be as wiſe at leaſt, as the Ways you take to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: I find, Madam, I am not to know what you intend to do; and I ſuppoſe I am to be eaſy at that too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: When I intend to marry him, I ſhall not care whether you are eaſy, or no.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: If your Indifference to me, were a Proof of your Inclination to him, the Gentleman need not deſpair.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, I'll endeavour to take your Advice, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: O! that won't coſt you much Trouble, I dare ſay, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: About as much, I ſuppoſe, as it coſt you to give it me.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Upon my Word, Madam, I gave it purely to oblige you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then to return your Civility, the leaſt I can do is to take it.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Is't poſſible? How can you torture me with this Indifference?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why do you inſult me with ſuch a bare-fac'd Jealouſy?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Is it a Crime to be concern'd for what becomes of you? Has not your Father openly declar'd againſt me, in Favour of my Rival? How is it poſſible, at ſuch a Time, not to have a thouſand Fears? What though they all are falſe and groundleſs, are they not ſtill the Effect of Love alarm'd, and anxious to be ſatisfied? I have an open, artleſs Heart, that cannot bear Diſguiſes, but when 'tis griev'd, in ſpite of me, 'twill ſhew it—Pray pardon me—But when I am told you went out in the utmoſt Hurry with ſome Writings to a Lawyer, and took the Doctor's own Servant with you, ev'n in the very Hour your Father had propos'd him, as your Husband!—Good Heaven! what am I to think? Can I, muſt I ſuppoſe my Senſes fail me? If I have Eyes, have Ears, and have a Heart, muſt it be ſtill a Crime to think I ſee, and hear—Yet by my Torments feel I love.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well! I own it looks ill-natur'd now, now, to ſhew him ſome Concern—but then this Jealouſy—I muſt, and will get th • better of.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Speak Maria, is ſtill my Jealouſy a Crime?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
If you ſ •• ll inſiſt on it, as a Proof of Love, then I muſt tell you, Sir, 'tis of that kind, that only ſlighted Hearts are pleas'd with; when I am ſo reduc'd, then I prehaps may bear it—The Fact you charge me with I grant is true, I have been Abroad, as you ſay: But ſtill let Appearance
look ne'er ſo pointing, while there is a Poſſibility in Nature, that what I have done may be innocent, I won't bear a Look, that tells me to my Face you dare ſuſpect me: If you have Doubts, why don't you ſatisfy them before you ſee me? Can you ſuppoſe, that I'm to ſtand confounded, as a Criminal before you? How deſpicable a Figure muſt a Woman make, to bear but ſuch a Moment? Come, come, there's nothing ſhews ſo low a Mind, as theſe grave, and inſolent Jealouſies. The Man, that's capable of ever ſeeing a Woman, after he believes her falſe, is capable on her Submiſſion, and a little Flattery, were ſhe really falſe, poorly to forgive and bear it.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: You won't find me, Madam, of ſo low a Spirit; but ſince I ſee your Tyranny ariſes from your mean Opinion of me, 'tis Time to be my ſelf, and diſavow your Power, you uſe it now beyond my bearing; not only impoſe on me to disbelieve my Senſes, but do it with ſuch an imperious Air, as if my Honeſt, manly Reaſon were your Slave, and this poor groveling Frame that follows you, durſt ſhew no Signs of Life, but what you deign to give it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh! you are in the right—go on—ſuſpect me ſtill, believe the worſt you can—'tis all true—I don't juſtify my ſelf—Why do you trouble me with your Complaints? If you are Maſter of that manly Reaſon you have boaſted, give me a manly Proof of it, at once reſume your Liberty, deſpiſe me, go, go off in Triumph now, and let me ſee you ſcorn the Woman, whoſe vile, o'er-bearing Falſhood, would inſult your Senſes.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: O Heaven! is this the End of all? Are then thoſe tender Proreſtations you have made me (for ſuch I thought them) when with the ſofteſt • ind Reluctance your riſing Bluſhes gave me ſomething more, than Hope—What all—O Maria! All but come to this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O Lud! I am growing ſilly, if I hear on, I ſhall tell him every thing; 'tis but another ſtruggle, and I ſhall conquer it—So ſo you ar • not gone, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Do you then wiſh me gone, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Your manly Reaſon will direct you.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: This is too much—my Heart can bear no more. O!—what? am I rooted here! 'Tis but a Pang, and I am free for ever.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: At laſt I am reliev'd! Well, Mr. Charles, is it done?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I did not ſtir from his Desk, Madam, till it was intirely finiſh'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Where's the Original?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: This is it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Very well, that, you know you muſt keep, but come, we muſt loſe no Time, we will examine this in the next Room. Now I feel for him.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: O Rage! Rage! this is not to be born—ſhe's gone, ſhe's loſt, ſordidly has ſold her ſelf to Fortune, and I muſt now forget her—Hold, if poſſible, let me cool a Moment—Intereſt! No, that could not tempt her—She knows I'm Maſter of a larger Fortune, than there her utmoſt Hopes can give her, that on her own Conditions ſhe may be mine:—But what's this ſecret Treaty then within! what's doing there! who can reſolve that Riddle?—And yet perhaps, like other Riddles, when 'tis explain'd, nothing may ſeem ſo eaſy: But why again, might ſhe not truſt me too with the Secret! That! that entangles all a-freſh, and ſets me on the Rack of Jealouſy.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: How now, Frank! what in a Rapture?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Prithee, pardon me, I am unfit to talk with you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What is Maria in her Airs again?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: I know not what ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Do you know where ſhe is?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Retir'd this Moment to her Chamber, with the Doctor's Servant.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why thou art not jealous of the Doctor, I hope?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Perhaps ſhe'll be leſs reſerv'd to you, and tell you wherein I have miſtaken her.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Poor Frank, thou art a perfect Sir Martin in thy Amours, every Plot I lay upon my Siſter's Inclination for thee, thou art ſure to ruin by thy own unfortunate Conduct.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: I own I have too little Temper, and too much real Paſſion for a modiſh Lover.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Come, come, prithee be eaſy once more, I'll undertake for you, if you'll fetch a cool Turn in the Park upon Conſtitution Hill, in leſs than half an Hour, I'll come to you.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Dear Tom, thou art a Friend indeed! O I have a Thouſand Things—but you ſhall find me there.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Poor Frank! now has he been taking ſome honeſt Pains to make himſelf miſerable.

div.p: How now, Siſter, what have you done to Heartly? The poor Fellow looks, as if he had kill'd your Parrot.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pſhah! you know him well enough, I have only been ſetting him a Love-Leſſon, it a little puzzles him to get through it at firſt, but he'll know it all by to morrow; you will be ſure to be in the way, Mr. Charles?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Madam, you may depend upon me, I have my full Inſtructions.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: O ho! There's the Buſineſs then, and it ſeems Heartly was not to be truſted with it; ha! ha! and prithee what is this mighty Secret, that's tranſacting between Charles and you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That's what he would have known indeed, but you muſt know, I don't think it proper to let you tell him neither, for all your ſly manner of asking.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: O! pray take your own Time, dear Madam, I am not in haſte to know, I can aſſure you, I came about another Affair, our Deſign upon the Doctor: Now while my Father takes his Nap after Dinner, would be the propereſt Time to put it in Execution: prithee go to my Lady, and perſwade her to it this Moment.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why won't you go with me?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, I'll place my ſelf unknown to her in this Paſſage; for, ſho • ld I tell her I deſign to over-hear him, ſhe might be ſcrupulous.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That's true—but hold, on ſecond Thoughts, you ſhall know part of this Affair between Charles and me; nay, I give you leave to tell it Heartly too, on ſome Conditions, 'tis true, I did deſign to have ſurpriz'd you, but now—my Mind's alter'd, that's enough.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ay, for any Mortal's Satisfaction—but here comes my Lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Away then to your Poſt—but let me ſee you, when this Affair is over.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I'll be with you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, Madam, has your Ladyſhip conſider'd my Brother's Propoſal about the Doctor?

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p:
I have Child, and am convinc'd it ought not to be delay'd a Moment: I have juſt ſent to ſpeak with him here—Sir John too preſſes me to give him a Hearing upon your Account: but muſt I play a treacherous Part now,
and inſtead of perſuading you to the Doctor, ev'n perſuade the Doctor againſt you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Dear Madam, don't be ſo nice, if Wives were never to diſſemble, what wou'd become of many wilful Husband's Happineſs?

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Nay, that's true too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'd give the World now methinks, to ſee this ſolemn Interview; ſure there can't be a more ridiculous Image, than unlawful Love peeping his ſly Head out from under the Cloak of Sanctity! O! that I were in your Ladyſhip's Place, I would lead that dancing Blood of his ſuch a profane Courant—your wiſe Fellows make the rareſt Fools too: But your Ladyſhip will make a Rogue of him, and that will do our Buſineſs at preſent.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: If he makes himſelf one, 'tis his own Fault.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Dear Madam, one Moment's Truce with the Prude, I beg you, don't ſtart at his firſt Declarations, but let him go on till he ſhews the very bottom of his ugly Heart.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, I'll give a good Account of him—here he comes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then I hope, Madam, you will give me Leave to be Commode, and ſteal off.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I am told, Madam, you deſign me the Happineſs of your Commands; I am proud you think me worthy of them in any ſort.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Pleaſe to ſit, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Did not Sir John inform you too, that I had deſir'd a private Conference with your Ladyſhip?

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: He did, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: 'Tis then by his Permiſſion we are thus happily alone.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: True, and 'tis on that Account, I wanted to adviſe with you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Well, but, dear Lady, ah! [ſighing] you can't conceive the Joyouſneſs I feel, in this ſo unexpected Interview, ah! ah! I have a Thouſand friendly Things to ſay to you—Ah! ah! and how ſtands your precious Health? Is your naughty Cold abated yet? I have ſcarce cloſed my Eyes theſe two Nights, with my Concern for you, and every watchful Interval has ſent a Thouſand Sighs and Prayers to Heaven for your Recovery.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Your Charity was too far concern'd for me.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Ah! don't ſay ſo, don't ſay ſo—you merit more, than mortal Man can do for you.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Indeed, you over-rate me.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I ſpeak it from my Soul! indeed! indeed! indeed! do.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: O dear! you hurt my Hand, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Impute it to my Zeal, and want of Words to expreſs my Heart; ah! I would not harm you for the World, no, bright Creature, 'tis the whole Buſineſs of my Soul to—

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: But to our Affair, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Ah! thou heavenly Woman!

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Your Hand need not be there, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Ah! I was admiring the Softneſs of this Silk, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Ay, but I am tickliſh.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: They are indeed come to a prodigious Perfection in this Manufacture—How wonderful is Humane Art!—Here it diſputes the Prize with Nature—that all this ſoft, and gaudy Luſtre, ſhould be wrought from the poor Labours of a Worm?

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: But our Buſineſs, Sir, is upon another Subject: Sir John informs me, that he thinks himſelf under no Obligation to Mr. Heartly, and therefore reſolves to give you Maria: Now pray be ſincere, and let me know what your real Intentions are?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Is it poſſible! Can you, Divine Perfection, be ſtill a Stranger to my real Thoughts? Has not one Action of my Life inform'd you better? Since I muſt plainly ſpeak them then, Maria's but a Feint, a Blind to ſcreen my real Thoughts from ſhrewd Suſpicion's Eye, and ſhield your ſpotleſs Fame from worldly Cenſure. Could you then think 'twas for Maria's ſake, your Balls, Aſſemblies, and your Toilet Viſits have been reſtrain'd? Would I have urged Sir John to make that Fence to incloſe a Butterfly? No, ſoft, and ſerious Excellence, your Virtues only were the Object of my Care, I could not bear to ſee the Gay, the Young, and the Inconſtant daily basking in your diffuſive Beams of Beauty, without a ſecret Grudg, I might ſay, Envy ev'n of ſuch Inſects Happineſs.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I take all this, as I ſuppoſe you intended it, for my Good, my ſpiritual Welfare.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Indeed I meant you ſerious, cordial Service.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: I dare ſay you did, you are above the low and momentary Views of this World.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Ah! I ſhould be ſo—and yet, alas! I find this mortal Cloathing of my Soul is made like other Mens, of ſenſual Fleſh and Blood, and has its Frailties.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: We all have thoſe, but yours I know, are well corrected by your divine, and virtuous Contemplations.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: And yet our Knowledge of Eternal Beauties, do not reſtrain us wholly from the love of all that's mortal—Beauty here, 'tis true muſt die, but while it lives, 'twas given us to admire, to wake the ſluggiſh Heart, and charm the ſenſible: At the firſt Sight of you, I felt unuſual Tranſports in my Soul, and trembled at the Guilt that might enſue; but on Reflection found my Flame receiv'd a Sanction from your Goodneſs, and might be reconcil'd with Virtue; on this I chaced my ſlandrous Fears, let in the harmleſs Paſſion at my Eyes, and gave up all my Heart to Love.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Indeed! ſo warm Sir Roger, but I ſhall cool your Paſſion with a Witneſs.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Theſe gay Profeſſions, Sir, ſhew more the Courtier than the Zealot; nor could I think a Mind ſo fortify as yours, could have been open to ſuch vain Temptation.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What Boſom can be Proof 'gainſt ſuch Artillery of Love? I may reſiſt, call all my Prayers, my Faſtings, Tears and Penance to my Aid, but yet, alas! theſe have not made an Angel of me: I am ſtill but Man, Virtue may ſtrive, but Nature will be uppermoſt: Permit me then on this fair Shrine to pay my Vows, and offer up a Heart—

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, you've ſaid enough to put you in my Power, ſuppoſe I now ſhould let my Husband, Sir, your Benefactor, know the Favour you deſign'd him.

sp.speaker: Doct
sp.p: You cannot be ſo cruel?

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Nor will, on one Condition.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Name it.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: That inſtantly you renounce all Claim and Title to Maria and uſe your utmoſt Intereſt with Sir John to give her with her full Fortune to Mr. Heartly: If you are wiſe, conſider on't

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Ha! the Colonel ther • ! his Father with him too! 〈◊〉 may have been ſome Treachery, what's to be done?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Now, Sir, let your Eyes convince you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: They do, that yours, Sir, have deceiv'd you, all this I knew of.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Obſerve, and be convinc'd.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I have it.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Methinks this Buſineſs needs not Sir, ſo long a Pauſe.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Madam, I cannot eaſily give up ſuch honeſt Hopes.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Honeſt!

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Perhaps my Years are thought unequal to my Flame, but, Lady, thoſe were found no ſtrong Objection 'twixt Sir John and you; and can you blame me then for following ſo ſure a Guide in the ſame youthful Path to Happineſs.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Is this your Reſolution then?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Will you let him go on, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, to confound your Slander.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Monſtrous

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Can you ſuppoſe my Heart leſs capable of Love than his? Is it for me to puſh the Bleſſing from me too; For tho' my Flame has been of long Duration, my conſcious want of Merit kept it ſtill conceal'd, till his good Nature brought it to this bleſt Occaſion; and can you then, ſo authoriz'd, refuſe your friendly Pity to my Sufferings? One Word from you compleats my Joy; in you, Madam, is my only Hope, my Fear, my Eaſe, my Pain, my Torment, or my Happineſs; Maria! O! Maria!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Confuſion!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Now, vile Detractor of all Virtue, is your outragious Malice yet confounded? Did I not tell you too, he only made an Intereſt here to gain your Siſter?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: His Devil has outreacht me.

sp.speaker: Sir. John.
sp.p: Is this your rank Detection of his Treachery?

sp.speaker: Doct. Sir
sp.p: John, I did not ſee you, Sir, I doubt you are come too ſoon, I have not yet prevail'd with her.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ah! good Man, be not concern'd your Trouble ſhall be ſhort • r for't, I'll force her to Complyance.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: What have you done—your Impatience has ruin'd all.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I ſ •• it now too late.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
Now, Sir! will your baſ • Pr • judice of Party never b • at reſt? Am I to be 〈◊〉 thought partial, blind, and obſtinate to favour ſo much injur'd Virtue; if thou art
a Man not loſt to Conſcience, or to Honour, then like a Man repair this Wrong, confeſs the Rancour of thy vile Suſpicion, and throw thee at his Feet for Pardon.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What mean you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: While he is in this Temper, he will not eaſily be undeceiv'd—I've yet an After game to play, till when, 'tis beſt to leave him in his Error.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What! mute! defenceleſs! hardned in thy Malice?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I ſcorn the Imputation, Sir, and with the ſame repeated Honeſty avow (howe'er his Cunning may have chang'd Appearances) that you are ſtill deceiv'd, that all I told you, Sir, was true, theſe Eyes theſe Ears were Witneſſes of his audacious Love, without the mention of my Siſter's Name, directly, plainly, groſly tending to abuſe the Honour of your Bed.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Audacious Monſter! were not your own Senſes Evidence againſt your frontleſs Accuſation? I ſee your Aim; Wife, Children, Servants, all are bent againſt him, and think to weary me by groundleſs Clamours to diſcard him, but all ſhall not do, your Malice on your own vile Heads; to me, it but the more endears him; either ſubmit, and ask his Pardon for this Wrong—

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Good Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Or this Inſtant leave my Sight, my Houſe, my Family for ever.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What means this Raſhneſs, Sir! on my Account it muſt not be, what would the World report of it? I grant it poſſible he loves me not, but you muſt grant it too as poſſible he might miſtake me! it muſt be ſo—He is too much your Son to do his Enemy a wilful Injury: If he, I ſay, ſuppos'd my Converſe with your Lady Criminal, to accuſe me then, was but the Error of his Virtue, not his Baſeneſs, you ought to love him, thank him for ſuch watchful Care: Was it for him to ſe • , as he believ'd, your Honour in ſo ſoul a danger, and ſtand concernleſs by? The Law of Heaven, of Nature, and of Filial Duty, all oblig'd him to allarm your Vengeance, and detect the Villany.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: O Miracle of Charity!

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Come, come, ſuch Breaches muſt not be, betwixt ſo good a Son, and Father▪ forget, forgive, embrace him, cheriſh him, and let me bleſs the Hour I was the Occaſion of ſo ſw •• t a Reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
I cannot bear ſuch Goodneſs! O ſink me not into the Earth with Shame—Hear this, perverſe and
Reprobate! O! couldſt thou wrong ſuch more than mortal Virtue!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Wrong him! the hardned Impudence of this painted Charity—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Peace, Monſter—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Is of a blacker, deeper Dye, than the great Devil himſelfin all his Triumphs over Innocence ever wore.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: O graceleſs Infidel!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, Sir, though I would hazard Life to ſave you from the Ruine he miſleads you to; could die to reconcile my Duty to your Favour; yet on the Terms that Villain offers, 'tis Merit to refuſe it; I glory in the Diſgrace your Errors give me—But, Sir, I'll trouble you no more: To Day is his—to Morrow may be mine.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I did not think he had had ſo hard a Nature.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: O, my good Lord, your charitable Heart diſcovers not the Rancour that's in his: but what better can be hoped for, from a Wretch ſo ſwell'd with Spleen, and Rage of Party.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No, no, Sir, I am the Thorn that galls him; 'tis me, 'tis me he hates; he thinks I ſtand before him in your Favour; and 'tis not fit indeed I ſhould do ſo; for fallen, as he is, he's ſtill your Son, and I alas! an Alien, an Intruder here, and ought in Conſcience to retire, and heal theſe hapleſs Breaches in your Family.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What means your Lordſhip?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: But I'll remove this Eye-ſore—Here Charles!—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: For Goodneſs ſake.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Bring me that Writing I gave you to lay up this Morning.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Now Fortune favour us, (Aſide) Exit Charles.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Make haſte, good Charles, it ſhall be ſign'd this Moment.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Not for the World; 'twas not to that End I ſent for it, but to refuſe your kind Intentions; for with your Chrildren's Curſes, Sir, I dare not, muſt not take it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nay good, my Lord, you carry it now too far; my Daughter is not wrong'd by it, but if not obſtinate may ſtill be happy; and for my wicked Son, ſhall he then Heir my Lands, to propagate more miſerable Schiſmaticks; No, let him depend on you, whom he has wrong'd; perhaps in Time, he may refl • ct upon his Father's Juſtice; be reconcil'd to your rewarded Virtues, and r • form his 〈◊〉 Errors.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: That would be indeed a Bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: If Heaven ſhould at laſt reclaim him, the Power to right him ſtill is yours; in you I know he yet would find a fond forgiving Father.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: The Imagination of ſo bleſt an Hour, ſoftens me to a Tenderneſs I can't ſupport.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: O the dear, good Man' come! come, let's in to execute this Deed.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Will you then force me to accept this Truſt? For, call it what you will, with me, it ſhall never be more than ſuch,

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Let that depend upon the Conduct of my Son.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Well. Sir, ſince yet it may prevent his Ruine, I conſent.
sp.l: So ſweet a Hope muſt all my Fears controul,
I take the Truſt, as Guardian to his Soul.

div.trailer: The End of the Third ACT.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: YOU were a Witneſs then?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I ſaw it ſign'd, ſeal'd, and deliver'd, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And all paſs'd without the leaſt Suſpicion?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Sir John ſign'd it with ſuch Earneſtneſs, and the Doctor receiv'd it with ſuch a ſeeming Reluctance, that neither had the Curioſity to examine a Line of it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Charles, whether it ſucceeds to our Ends, or not, we have ſtill the ſame Obligations to you: You ſaw with what a friendly Warmth my Brother heard your Story, and I don't in the leaſt doubt his Succeſs in your Affair at Court.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: What I have done, my Duty bound me to: But pray, Madam, give me leave, without Offence, to ask you one innocent Queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Freely, Sir.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Have you never ſuſpected then, that in all this Affair I have had ſome ſecret, ſtronger Motive to it, than barely Duty?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes—but have you been in no Apprehenſions I ſhould diſcover that Motive?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Pray, pardon me, I ſee already, I have gone too far.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not at all, it loſes you no Merit with me, nor is it in my Nature to uſe any one ill, that loves me, unleſs I lov'd that one again, then indeed, there might be Danger—Come, don't look grave, my Inclinations to another, ſhall not hinder me paying every One, what's due to their Merit, I ſhall therefore always think my ſelf oblig'd to treat your Misfortunes and your Modeſty with the utmoſt Tenderneſs.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: By the dear, ſoft Eaſe you have given my Heart, I never hoped for more.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then I'll give you a great deal more, and to ſhew my particular good Opinion of you, I'll do you a Favour, Mr. Charles, I never did any Man ſince I was born—I'll be ſincere with you.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Is it then poſſible you can have lov'd another, to whom you never were ſincere?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Alas! you are but a Novice in the Paſſion—Sincerity is a dangerous Virtue, and often ſurfeits what it ought to nouriſh; therefore I take more Pains to make the Man I love believe I ſlight him, than (if poſſible) I would to convince you of my Eſteem and Friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Be but ſincere in that, Madam, and I can't complain.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, I'll give you a Proof of it, I'll ſhew you all the Good-nature you can deſire; you ſhall make what Love to me you pleaſe now; but then I'll tell you the Conſequence, I ſhall certainly be pleas'd with it, and that will flatter you, till I do you a Miſchief. Now do you think me ſincere?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I ſcarce conſider that, but I'm ſure you are agreeable.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why look you there now! do you conſider, that a Woman had as live be thought agreeable, as handſome? And how can you ſuppoſe, from one of your Senſe, that I am not pleas'd with being told ſo?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Was ever Temper ſo enchanting?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Or Vanity more venial! I'm pleas'd with you.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Diſtracting! ſure never was Deſpair adminiſtred with a Hand ſo gentle.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: So! now you have convinc'd me, I have a good Underſtanding too—Why I ſhall certainly have the better Opinion of yours, for finding it out now.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Your good Opinion's what I aim at.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ay, but the more I give it you, the better you'll think of me ſtill; and then I muſt think the better of you again, and then you the better of me upon that too; and ſo at laſt I ſhall think ſeriouſly, and you'll begin to think ill of me. But I hope, Mr. Charles, your good Senſe will prevent all this.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I ſee my Folly now, and bluſh at my Preſumption: but yet to cure my weaning Heart, and reconcile me to my Doom, be yet ſincere, and ſatisfy one ſickly Longing of my Soul.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: To my Power, command me.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: O! tell me then the Requiſites I want, and what's the ſecret Charm that has preferr'd my Rival to your Heart.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Come then, be chearful, and I'll anſwer like a Friend. The Gentleneſs, and Modeſty of your Temper, would make with mine but an unequal Mixture: with
you I ſhou'd be ungovernable, not know my ſelf; your Compliance would undo me. I am by Nature Vain, Thoughtleſs, Wild, and Wilful; therefore ask a higher Spirit to controul and lead me. For whatever outward Airs I give my ſelf, I am within convinc'd, a Woman makes a very wrong Figure in Happineſs, that does not think Superiority beſt becomes her Huſband—But what's yet more tho' I confeſs you have Qualities uncommon in your Sex, and ſuch as ought to warm a Heart to love; yet here you come too late; Compaſſion's all within my Power: And I know you cannot but have ſeen, I am under Obligations, I need not explain to you.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I am ſatisfied—You treat me with ſo kind and gentle a Concern, that I muſt ſubmit to it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well when all's done, he's a pretty Fellow; and the firſt ſure, that ever heard Reaſon againſt himſelf with ſo good an Underſtanding.

div.stage: Enter a Servant with a Letter to Charles.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, the Colonel order'd me to give this into your own Hands.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: From my Brother?—Where is he?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I left him, Madam, at the Secretary's-Office with one Sir Charles Trueman, and Mr. Heartly.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Ha! my Father! O! Heaven, 'tis his Hand too! Now I tremble!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come, Sir, take heart; I dare ſay there's good News in't, and I ſhould be glad to hear it—But no Ceremony; pray read to your ſelf firſt.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Since you command me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.p: Lord! how one may live and learn! I could not have believ'd, that Modeſty in a young Fellow could have been ſo amiable a Virtue: and though, I own, there is I know not what of dear Delight in indulging one's Vanity with them; yet, upon ſerious Reflection. we muſt confeſs, that Truth and Sincerity have a Thouſand Charms beyond it. And I now find more Pleaſure in my ſelf-denying Endeavours to make this poor Creature eaſy, than ever I took in humbling the Airs and Aſſurance of a Man of Quality—I believe I had as good confeſs all this to Heartly, and ev'n make up the Buſtle with him too—But then he will ſo teaze one for Inſtances of real Inclination—O God—I can't bear the Thought on't—And yet we muſt come together too—Well! Nature knows the way to be ſure, and ſo I'll ev'n truſt to her ſor't—Bleſs me! What's the Matter? you ſeem concern'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: I am indeed, but 'tis with Joy! O! Madam! my Father's reconcil'd to me: This Letter is from him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pray let's hear.

body.p: This Day, by Colonel Woodvil, I receiv'd the joyful News of your being yet alive, and well: Though that's but half my Comfort. He has aſſur'd me too, you have renounc'd thoſe Principles, that made me think your Death my Happineſs. The Services you have intended his Family, and may do the Government, in your juſt Detection of a Traytor that would ruin both, have been ſo well receiv'd at Court, and ſo generouſly repreſented there by the Colonel and Mr. Heartly, that they have obtain'd an Order for your Pardon; which I now ſtay the paſſing of, before I throw my Arms about you, that I may have no Doubt or Fear behind to interupt the Fulneſs of my Joy. I am inform'd, that in revealing your ſelf to a certain fair Lady, you have let fall ſome Words, that ſhew you have an innocent tho' hopeleſs Paſſion for her. Your Youth excuſes what is paſt; but now conſider how far you owe your Life to Mr. Heartly: I therefore charge you, on my Bleſſing, to give up every idle Thought of Love, that may interrupt his Happineſs, or abate the Merit of what you've done to deſerve the Pardon of your Sovereign, or of your affectionate forgiving Father,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I an overjoy'd at your good Fortune.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: You, Madam, are the Scource of all—but I am now unfit to thank you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You owe me nothing, Sir; Succeſs was all I hoped for.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.p: Pray excuſe me—It would be Rudeneſs to trouble you with the tender Thoughts this muſt give a Heart oblig'd like mine.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Poor Creature how full his honeſt Heart is? What early Viciſſitudes of Fortune has he run through? Well! this was handſomely done of Heartly, conſidering what he had felt upon his Account, to be ſo concern'd for his Pardon.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Dear Maria, what will become of us? The Tyranny of this ſubtle Prieſt is inſupportable: He has ſo fortified himſelf in Sir John's Opinion by this laſt Miſconduct of your Brother, that I begin to loſe my uſual Power with him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pray explain, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: In ſpight of all I cou'd urge, he is this Minute bringing the Doctor to make his Addreſſes to you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am glad on't: for the Beſt muſt come like a Bear to the Stake, I'm ſure: He knows I ſhall bait him.

sp.speaker: Lady. W.
sp.p: No, no, he preſſes it, to keep Sir John ſtill blind to his wicked Deſign upon me—Therefore I came to give you notice, that you might be prepar'd to receive him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am oblig'd to your Ladyſhip: Our Meeting will be a tender Scene, no doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: You have heard, I ſuppoſe, what an extravagant Settlement your Father has ſign'd to.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; but I am glad your Ladyſhip's like to be a Gainer by it, however: For when I marry, it will be without the Doctor's Conſent, depend upon't.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: No, Child, I did not come into Sir John's Family with a Deſign to injure it, or make any one of it my Enemy: Whenever that Four Thouſand Pound falls into my Hands, you'll find it as firmly yours, as if it had been given you, without that odious Condition.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Madam, I think my ſelf as much oblig'd by this kind Intention, as the Performance: But if your Ladyſhip could yet find a way to prove this Hypocrite a private Villain to my Father, I am not without Hopes the Publick will ſoon have enough againſt him, to give a Turn to the Settlement.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe that fails, what will become of your poor Brother?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But, dear Madam, I cannot ſuppoſe this Fellow muſt not be hang'd at laſt; and then, you know, the ſame honeſt Hand that ties him up, releaſes the Settlement.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Not abſolutely, neither; for this very Houſe is given him in preſent, which, tho' that were to be the End of him, would then be ſorfeited.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, then my Brother muſt ev'n petition the Government. There have been Preſidents of the ſame Favour, Madam. If not, he muſt pay for his Blundering, and lay his next Plot deeper, I think.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: I am glad you are ſo chearful upon it, however; it looks as if you had ſomething in Petto to depend upon. But here comes the Doctor.

div.stage: Enter Sir John, with the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
Daughter, ſince you have the Happineſs to be thought Amiable in the Eye of this Good Man, I expect you
give him an inſtant Opportunity to improve it into an Amity for Life.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, I ſhall give him no Occaſion to alter his Opinion of me.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Why, that's well ſaid; come, Sweet-heart, we'll uſe no Ceremony.
sp.stage: [Exit Sir John, with Lady W. Marra and the Doctor ſtand ſome Time mute, in formal Civilities, and a conſcious Contempt of each other.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pleaſe to ſit, Sir.—What can the ugly Cur ſay to me? He ſeems a little puzzled. This puts me in mind of the tender Interview between Lady Charlotte, and Lord Hardy in the Funeral.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Look you, fair Lady, not to make many Words, I am convinc'd, notwithſtanding your good Father's Favour, I am not the Perſon you deſire to be alone with, upon this Occaſion.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Your Modeſty—is pleas'd to be in the right, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Humh! if I don't flatter my ſelf, you have always had a very ill Opinion of me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: A worſe, Sir, of no Mortal breathing,

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Humh! and it is likely, it may he immoveable,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No Rock ſo firm.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Humh! from theſe Premiſes then, I may reaſonably conclude—you hate me heartily.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Moſt ſincerely, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Well there is, however, ſome Merit in ſpeaking Truth; therefore to be as juſt on my ſide, I ought in Conſcience to let you know, that I have as cordial a Contempt for you too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O! fy! you flatter me.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Indeed I don't; you wrong your own Imperfections to think ſo.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Theſe Words from any Tongue but yours, might ſhock me; but coming from the only Man I hate—they charm me.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Admirable! there ſeems good Senſe in this: Have you never obſerv'd, Madam, that ſometimes the greateſt Diſcords raiſe the moſt agreeable Harmony?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes. But what do you infer from thence?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: That while we ſtill preſerve this Temper in our Hate, a mutual Benefit may riſe from it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O! never fear me, Sir; I ſhall not fly out; being convinc'd, that nothing gives ſo ſharp a Point to one's A verſion, as good Breeding; as, on the contrary, ill Manners often hide a ſecret Inclination

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Moſt accurately diſtinguiſh'd—Well, Madam, is there no Project you can think of now, to turn this mutual A verſion, as I ſaid, into a mutual Benefit?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: None, that I know of, unleſs we were to marry for our mutual Mortification.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What would you give then, to avoid marrying me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My Life, with Joy, if Death alone cou'd ſhun you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: When you marry any other Perſon—my Conſent is neceſſary.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: So I hear indeed—But pray, Doctor, tell me, how could your Modeſty receive ſo inſolent a Power, without putting my poor Father out of Countenance with your Bluſhes?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You over-rate my Prudence: I ſought it not, but he would crowd it in among other Obligations: He is good-natur'd, and I could not ſhock him by a Refuſal. Wou'd you have had me plainly told him, what a deſpicable Opinion I had of his Daughter?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Or rather, what a favourable one you had of his Wife, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Humh! you ſeem to loſe your Temper.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why do you ſuppoſe, the whole Family does not ſee it except my Father?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: If you will keep your Temper, I have ſomething to propoſe to you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Your Reproof is juſt; but I only rais'd my Voice, to let you know, I know you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You might have ſpar'd your Pains, it being of no Conſequence to my Propoſal, what you think of me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not unlikely Come, Sir, I am ready to receive it.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: In one Word then—I take it for granted, that you would marry Mr. Heartly—Am I right?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Once in your Life, you are.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Nay, no Compliments; let us be plain—Would you marry him?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You are mighty nice, methinks—Well—I would.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Then I won't conſent to it—Now, if you have any Propoſal to make me—ſo—if not, our Amour's at an end; and we part as Civil Enemies, as if he had been married this Twelvemonth—Think of it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O the mercenary Villain, he wants to have a Fellow feeling, I find—What ſhall I do with him—bite him—pretend to comply, and make my Advantage of it—Well, Sir, I underſtand every thing but the Sum—if we agree upon that, it's a Bargain.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Half.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What, Two Thouſand Pound for your Conſent only?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why, is not Two Thouſand Pound worth Two Thouſand Pound? Don't you actually get ſo much by it? Is not the half better than nothing? Come, come, ſay, I have us'd you like a Friend.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay, I think it's the only civil Thing you have done, ſince you came into the Family.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Do you then make your Advantage of it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why, as you ſay Doctor, 'tis better than nothing. But how is my Father to be brought into this?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Leave that to my Management.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What Security tho' do you expect for this Money?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: O! when I deliver my Conſent in Writing, Heartly ſhall lay it me down in Bank-Bills.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well! on one Proviſo, I'll undertake that too.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Name it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Upon your immediately owning to my Father, that you are willing to give up your Intereſt to Mr. Heartly.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Humh! ſtay—I agree to it—you ſhall have Proof of it this Evening—But in the mean time, let me warm you too; Don't expect, after I have hinted what you deſire to your Father, to make your Advantages now by betraying me to him. You know my Power there; if you do, I can eaſily give it a Counter-Turn: So diſcover what you pleaſe, I ſhall only pity you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O! I ſhall not ſtand in my own Light; I know your Power, and your Conſcience too well, dear Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Nay, I dare depend upon your being true to your own Intereſt. Here comes your Father, I will break it to him immediately. You'll prepare Mr. Heartly in the mean time.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Without fail.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I am ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Well, Sir, is my Daughter prudent? Has ſhe at laſt, a true and virtuous Senſe of Happineſs?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: She underſtands me better than I hoped, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well ſaid Equivocation.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, Sir John, we'll take a Turn in the Garden, I have ſomething there to offer to you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Sir,—Maria.—There's a Toy for thee—Now thou art again my Daughter
Come, Sir, I wait on you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What this Fellow's Original was, I know not; but by his Conſcience and Cunning, he would make an admirable Jeſuit—Here comes my Brother, and I hope with a good Account of him—Well! Brother, What Succeſs?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: All that my honeſt Heart could wiſh for—Subſtantial Affidavits! that will puzzle him to Anſwer; I have planted a Meſſenger at the next Door, who has a Warrant in his Pocket, when I give the Word, to take him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why ſhould not you do it immediately, he's now in the Garden with my Father.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No; our ſeizing him now for Treaſon, I am afraid won't convince my Father of his Villany: My Deſign is not only to get my Father out of his Hands, but to drive the pernicious Principles he has inſtill'd, out of my Father too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That I doubt will be difficult.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Not at all, if we can firſt prove him a private Villain to him. My Father's Honeſty will ſoon reflect, and may receive as ſudden a Turn as his Credulity.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That's true again; and I hope I am furniſh'd with a new Occaſion to begin the Alarm to him.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Pray what is't?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not to trouble you with Particulars; but in ſhort, I have agreed with the Doctor, that Heartly ſhall give him Two Thouſand Pounds for his Conſent without which, you know, by my Father's late Settlement, Heartly and I can never come together.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And does the Monſter really inſiſt upon't?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Not only that, but ev'n defies me to make an Advantage of the Diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: One would think the Villain ſuſpects his Footing in the Family is but ſhort-liv'd, he is in ſuch Haſte to have his Pennyworths out on't. But prithee, Siſter, What Secret's this, that you have yet behind in thoſe Writings that Charles brought to you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O! that's what I can't yet tell you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, pray?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Becauſe, when you have done all you can, I am reſolv'd to reſerve ſome Merit againſt him to my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: But why do you ſuppoſe I would not aſſiſt in it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You can't, it's now too late.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Pſhah! this is raſh, and ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ay, may be ſo; I ſuppoſe Heartly will be of that Opinion too: But if he is, you had better adviſe him to keep it to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You will have your obſtinate Way, I find.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: It can't be worſe than yours, I'm ſure; remember how you came off in your laſt Project; I know you meant well, but you are diſinherited for all that.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That's no Surprize to me; but I am aſham'd however.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: By the way; What have you done with Heartly? why is he not here?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: He has been here, but you muſt excuſe him; he was obliged to call in Haſte for Charles, whom he took home with him in his own Coach, where his Father waited to receive him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The poor Boy by this Time then has ſeen him. Sure their meeting muſt have been a moving Sight; I would give the World methinks for a true Account of it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You'll have it from Heartly by and by; 'tis at his Houſe they meet: The Father, Sir Charles Trueman, hapned to be Heartly's intimate Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well! I own Heartly has gained upon me by this.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am glad to hear that at leaſt. But I muſt let my Lady know what Progreſs we have made in the Doctor's Buſineſs, and beg her Aſſiſtance to finiſh him.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Madam, Mr. Heartly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Deſire him to walk in.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: To find you thus alone, Madam, was an Happineſs I did not expect from the Temper of our laſt parting,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I ſhould have been as well pleas'd now to have been thank'd as reproach'd for my good Nature; but you will be in the Right, I find.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Indeed you took me wrong; I literally meant that I was afraid you would not ſo ſoon think I had deſerv'd this Favour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, then, one of us has been in the Wrong at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: 'Twas I, I own it—More is not in my Power; all the Amends that have been, I have made you: My very Joy of ſeeing you, has waited, till what you had at Heart unask'd, was perfected; my own Pardon was poſtpon'd, till I had ſecur'd one ev'n for a Rival's Life, whom you ſo juſtly had compaſſionated.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pooh! but why would you ſay unask'd now? Don't you conſider your doing it ſo, is half the Merit of the Action?—Lord you have no Art; you ſhould have left me to have taken Notice of that; only imagine now, how kind, and handſome an Acknowledgment you have robb'd me of?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: And yet how artfully you have paid it? With what a wanton, charming Eaſe you play upon my Tenderneſs?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, but was not you ſilly now?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Come—You ſhall not be ſerious—You can't be more agreeable.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O! but I am ſerious.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Then I'll be ſo—Do you forgive me all?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What.
sp.stage: [Looking on her Fan, as not hearing him.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Are we Friends, Maria?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O Lord! but you have told me nothing of poor Charles; Pray how did his Father receive him?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Muſt you needs know that, before you anſwer me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Lord! you are never well till you have talk'd one out of Countenance.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Come, I won't be too particular, you ſhall anſwer nothing—Give me but your Hand only.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pſhah! I won't pull off my Glove, not I.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: I'll take it as it is then.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Lord! there, there, eat it, eat it.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: And ſo I could by Heav'n.
sp.stage: [Kiſſes 〈◊〉 eagerly, and pulls off her Glove.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O my Glove! my Glove! my Glove!—Pooh! you are in a perfect Storm! Lord! if you make ſuch a Rout with ones Hand only, What would you do if you had ones Heart?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: That's impoſſible to tell—But you were asking me of Charles, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O! ay, that's true! Well, now you are good again—Come tell me all that Affair, and then you ſhall ſee—how I will like you.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: O! that I could thus play with Inclination!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pſhah! but you don't tell me now.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: There is not much to tell—Where two ſuch tender Paſſions met, Words had but faintly ſpoke them. The Son conducted to the Door, with ſudden Fear ſtopt ſhort, and burſting into Sights, o'er chang'd with Shame, and Joy, had almoſt fainted in my Arms: The Father, touch'd with his Concern, mov'd forward with a kindly Smile to meet him. At this he took new Life, and ſpringing from his Hold, fell proteſtate at his Feet; where mute, and trembling, for a while he lay: At length with ſtreaming Eyes, and faultring Tongue, he begg'd his Bleſſing, and his Pardon. The tender Father caught him in his Arms, and dropping his fond Head upon his Cheek, kiſs'd him, and ſigh'd out, Heaven protect thee! then gave into his hand the Royal Pardon; and turning back his Face to dry his Manly Eyes, he cry'd, Deſerve this Royal Mercy, Charles, and I am ſtill thy Father. The grateful Youth. raiſing his Heart-ſwollen Voice, reply'd, May Heaven preſerve the Royal Life that gave it. But here, their Paſſions grew too ſtrong for farther Speech: Silent Embraces, alternate Sighs, and mingling Tears, were all their Language now. The moving Scene became too tender for my Eyes, and call'd methought, for Privacy; there unperceiv'd I left them, to recover into breathing Senſe, and utterable Joy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well! of all the inmoſt Tranſports of the Soul, there's none that dance into the Heart, like Friendly Reconcilements.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Thoſe Tranſports might be ours, Maria, would you bu • try your Power to pardon.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Which of thoſe Two now do you think was happieſt at that Meeting?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: O! the Father, doubtleſs; Great Souls feel a kind of honeſt Glory in Forgiving, that far exce • ds the Tranſport of receiving Pardon.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now I think to bend the ſtubborn Mind to ask it, is an equal Conqueſt; and the Joy ſuperior to receive, where the Heart wiſhes to be under Obligations.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Put me into the happy Boy's Condition, and I may then, perhaps, reſolve you better.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You ſhall poſitively bring him into Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Upon my Word I will.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And ſhew him to all the Women of Taſte; and I'll have you call him my pretty Fellow too.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: I will indeed: But hear me—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'm poſitive, if he had White Stockings he would cut down all the Danglers at Court in a Fortnight!

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: O! no doubt on't; but—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You can't conceive how prettily he makes Love now.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Not ſo well, as you make your Defence, Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O Lord! I had forgot—he's to teach me Greek too.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: O, the trifling Tyrant! How long, Maria, do you think you can find out new Evaſions for what I ſay unto you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Lord, you are horrid ſilly! But ſince 'tis Love that makes you ſuch a Dunce—poor Heartly,—I forgive you.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: That's kind, however—But to compleat my Joy, be kinder yet—and—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O! I can't, I can't—Lord! did you never ride a Horſe-Match?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Was ever ſo wild a Queſtion?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Becauſe if you have, it runs in my Head, you certainly gallop'd a Mile beyond the Winning Poſt, to make ſure on't.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Now I underſtand you: But ſince you will have me touch every Thing ſo very tenderly, Maria, How ſhall I find proper Words to ask you the Lover's laſt neceſſary Queſtion?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: O! there's a Thouſand Points to be adjuſted, before that's anſwer'd.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Name them this Moment then, for poſitively this is the laſt Time of asking.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pſhah! Who ſent for you?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I only came to teach you to ſpeak plain Engliſh, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Lord! mind your own Buſineſs, can't you?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: So I will; for I will make you do more of yours in Two Minutes, than you would have done without me in a Twelvemonth. Why, how now! What! do you think the Man's to dangle after your ridiculous Airs for ever?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: This is mighty pretty.

sp.speaker: Col
sp.p: You'll ſay ſo on Thurſday Sevenight, (for let Affairs take what Turn they will in the Family); that's poſitively your Wedding Day—Nay, you ſhan't ſtir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Was ever ſuch Aſſurance?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Upon my Life, Madam, I am out of Countenance: I don't know how to behave my ſelf to him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, no, let him go on, only—This is beyond whatever was known, ſure!

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Admirable! I hope it will come to ſomething.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ha! ha! If I were to leave you to yourſelves now, what a Couple of pretty out of Countenance Figures you would make; Humming and Hawing upon the vulgar 〈◊〉 of Jointure, and Pin Money—Come, come! I know what's proper o'both Sides, you ſhall leave it to me,

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: I had rather Maria would name her own Terms to me▪

sp.speaker: Col
sp.p: Have you a Mind to any Thing particular?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why ſure! What! Do you think I'm only to be fill'd out here as you pleaſe, and ſweetned, and ſupp'd up like a Diſh of 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, pray Madam, when your Tea's ready, what have you to do but to drink it? But you, I ſuppoſe, expect a Lover's Heart, like your Lamp, ſhould be always flaming at your Elbow, and when it's ready to go out, you indolently ſupply it with the Spirit of Contraction.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And ſo you ſuppoſe, that your Aſſurance has made an End of this Matter?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Not till you have given him your Hand upon it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That then would compleat it?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Perfectly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why then take it, Heartly.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: O ſoft Surprize! Exſtatick Joy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now I preſume you are in high Triumph, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: No, Siſter, now you are conſiſtent with that good Senſe I always thought you Miſtreſs of.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I'm afraid, Mr. Heartly, we are both oblig'd to him.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: If you think ſo, Maria, my Heart—Is under double Obligations laid.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: —If it cements our Friendſhip, I am overpaid.

div.head: ACT. V.
Heartly, and Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: WELL, now, Heartly, you have nothing to do but to look forward, and, if poſſible, to forget what I have been to you: Though 'tis a horrid Reſtraint you lay upon our Sex: You firſt make it the Buſineſs of your Lives to blow up our Vanity, and then prepoſterouſly expect we ſhould be prudent and humble: That is, you invite us to a Feaſt, where 'tis criminal to taſte, or have an Appetite; You put a Sword into a Child's Hand, and then are angry if it does Miſchief.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: You give up too much, Maria; I never treated you ſo: What might have been Flattery to moſt Women, was but honeſt Truth to you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why look there now! Is not that enough to turn any poor Woman into a Changeling?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: No, becauſe 'tis true; charge me with a Falſhood and I ſubmit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Nay then, did you not once tell me, that all my Airs and Follies were merely put on in Compliance to the World, and that good Senſe was only natural to me; that ev'n my Affectation (I have not forgot your Words) carried more Sincerity, than the ſerious Vows of other Women.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: By all my Happineſs I think ſo ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What, ſeriouſly?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Upon my Soul I do.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Lord! that's delightful! Do you really love me then, Heartly? Do, tell me, for now I begin to believe every Thing you ſay to me. But don't neither—I am vain ſtill—'Twas my Vanity that made me ask you.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Now I don't take it ſo.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: There was ſome in't I am ſure, tho' it begins to dwindle, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: No matter, I love you as you are, I would not have you loſe your Pleaſantry, Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, do, let me be ſilly ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: O! I can play with you, for that Matter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pſhah! you'll laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Not while you are good in Eſſentials.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Indeed I'll be very good.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: O fy! that will be the way to make me ſo.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Lord! What ſignifies Senſe, where there is ſo much Pleaſure in Folly?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: No perfect Paſſion ever was without it; the Pleaſure would ſubſide were we always to be wiſe in it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: For my Part I think ſo: But will you really ſtand to the Agreement tho', that I have made with the Doctor?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Why not? You ſhall not break your Word upon my Account, tho' he might be a Villain you gave it to.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well, I take it as a Compliment; not but I have ſome Hopes of getting over it, and juſtly too; but don't let me tell you now. I love to ſurprize—Tho' you ſhall know all, if you deſire it.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: No, Maria, I don't want the Secret; I am ſatisfied in your Inclination to truſt me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Well then, I'll keep the Secret, only to ſhew you, that you upon Occaſion may truſt me with one.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: After that, Maria, it would be wronging you to ask it: But pray, Madam, has the Doctor yet given you any Proof ofhis having declin'd his Intereſt to your Father?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes, he told me juſt now, he had brought him to pauſe upon it, and does not queſtion in Two Days to compleat it; but deſires in the mean Time you will be ready and punctual with the Proemium.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Suppoſe I ſhould talk with Sir John my ſelf; 'tis true he has ſlighted me of late, but however, I ought at leaſt to ask his Conſent, though I have but little Hopes of it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: By all Means, do ſo—Here he comes—This may open another Scene of Action too, that we are preparing for.

div.stage: Enter Sir John, and Lady Woodvil, who walks apart with Maria.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Mr. Heartly, I am glad I have met with you here.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: I have endeavour'd twice to Day, Sir, to pay my Reſpects to you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
Sir, I'll be plain with you—I went out to avoid you; but where the Welfare of a Child is concern'd
you muſt not take it ill, if we don't ſtand upon Ceremony.—However, ſince I have Reaſon now to be more in Temper, than perhaps I was, at that Time, I ſhould be glad to talk with you.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: I take it as a Favour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Sir,—Doctor Wolf informs me, that he is well aſſured you were horn the Year before the Revolution: Now Sir, I ſhould be glad to be well ſatisfied in that Points a greater Conſequence depending on it, perhaps, than you imagine.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Sir, I have been always told that was my Age; but for your farther Satisfaction I appeal to the Regiſter.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Sir, I dare believe you, and am glad to hear it,

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: But pray, Sir, may I beg leave to aſk, why you are ſo concerned to know this?

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: Becauſe, Sir, if this be true, I am ſatisfied you may be a regular Chriſtian; the Doubt of which, may have, perhaps, done you ſome Diſſervice in my private Opinion.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Sir, if that can reconcile me to it, I ſhall be thankful for the Benefit, without conſidering why I that way came to deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Sir Jo.
sp.p: That Argument might hold us now too long.—But, Sir,—here's the Caſe—your Principles and mine have the Misfortune to differ: Yours being (as I take it) entirely on the Revolution Side.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: If I am not miſinform'd, Sir, you your ſelf commanded a Regiment in Defence of it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I did ſo, and thought it juſt.—'Twould be fruitleſs, perhaps, to offer you the Reaſons, that ſince have alter'd my Opinion: But now, Sir, even ſuppoſing that I err in Principle, you muſt ſtill allow, that Conſcience is the Rule that every honeſt Man ought to walk by.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: 'Tis granted, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Then give me leave to tell you, Sir, that giving you my Daughter, would be to act againſt that Conſcience I pretend to, and conſequently the ſame Ties oblige me to beſtow her, where the ſame Principles with mine, I think deſerve her.—Now, Sir, conſult your own Honour, and tell me, how you can ſtill purſue my Daughter, without doing Violence to mine?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: But, Sir, to ſhorten this Diſpute, ſuppoſe the Doctor (whom I preſume you deſign her for) actually conſents to give me up his Intereſt; might not that ſoften your Objections to me?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But why do you ſuppoſe, Sir, he would give up his Intereſt?

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: I only judge from what your Daughter tells me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: My Daughter!

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: I appeal to her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And I appeal ev'n to your ſelf, Sir—Has not the Doctor juſt now in the Garden ſpoke in Favour of Mr. Heartly to you? Nay, pray, Sir, be plain, becauſe more depends on that, than you can eaſily imagine or believe.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What ſenſeleſs Inſinuation have you got in your Head now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Be ſo kind, Sir, firſt to anſwer me, that I may be better able to inform you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Well, I own he has declined his Intereſt, in Favour of Mr. Heartly. But I muſt tell you, Madam, he did it in ſo modeſt, ſo friendly, ſo good-natur'd, ſo conſcientious a Manner, that I now think my ſelf more than ever bound in Honour to eſpouſe him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: But now, Sir, (only for Arguments Sake) ſuppoſe I could prove, that all this ſeeming Virtue was utterly Artificial; that his Regard to Mr. Heartly was neither founded upon Modeſty, Friendſhip, Good-Nature, nor Conſcience; or in ſhort, that he has baſely betray'd and ſold the Truſt you made him; like a Villain barter'd, bargain'd to give me to Mr. Heartly, for half the Four Thouſand Pound you have valued his Conſent at. I ſay, ſuppoſe this were the Caſe, where would be his Virtue then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And I ſay 'tis impious to ſuppoſe it.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: Under Favour, Sir, how is it poſſible your Daughter could know the Doctor had ſpoke to you upon this Head, if he himſelf had not told her ſo, in Conſequence of his Agreement?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Sir, I don't admit your Conſequence: Her knowing it from him is no Proof, that he might not ſtill reſign her from a Principle of Modeſty or Good Nature.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Then, Sir, from what Principle muſt you ſuppoſe that I accuſe him?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: From an obſtinate Prejudice to all that's Good and Virtuous.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: That's too hard, Sir, What Blot has ſtain'd my Life, that you can think ſo of me▪ But, Sir, the worſt your Opinion can provoke me to, is to marry Mr. Heartly, without either his Conſent or yours.

sp.speaker: S • r John.
sp.p: What, do you brave me Madam?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No Sir, but I Scarn a Lye, and will ſo far vindicate my Integrity, as to inſiſt on your believing me▪ if not, as a Child whom you abandon, I have a right to throw my ſelf into other Arms for Protection.

sp.speaker: Hear.
sp.p: O Maria! how thy Spirit Charms me!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I am Confounded! thoſe Tears cannot be Counterfeit, nor can this be True.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Indeed my Dear, I fear it is, it would be Cruel to her Concern to think it wholly falſe, can you ſuppoſe ſhe'd urge ſo groſs an Accuſation only to expoſe her ſelf to the Juſtice of your Reſentment?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What are you againſt him too? then he has no Friend but me, and I cannot, at ſo ſhort a warning, give him up to Infamy, and Baſeneſs.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Good Sir, be Compos'd, and ask your Heart one farther Queſtion:

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What would you ſay to me?

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: In all our mutual Courſe of Happineſs, have I ever yet deceiv'd you with a falſhood?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Never, I grant it, nor has my Honeſt Heart yet Wrong'd thy Goodneſs with a Jealous Thought of it.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Would you then believe me, ſhould I accuſe him too? even of Crimes, that Vertue Bluſhes but no mention.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: To what Extravagance would you drive me?

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: I would before have undeceiv'd you, when his late Artifice turn'd the Honeſt Duty of your Son, into his own Reproach, and Ruine: But knowing then your Temper was inacceſſible, I durſt not offer it. But now, in better Hope of being believ'd, I here avow the Truth of all he was accus'd of then.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Will you Diſtract me? my Senſes could not be deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Indeed, they were, he ſaw you liſtning, and at the Inſtant turn'd his Impious Barefac'd Leve to me, into Equivocal Interceſſions pretending to Maria.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You Starrle me.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Could you otherwiſe ſuppoſe, your Son would have brought you to be Witneſs of his own Weak Malice in Accuſing him?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I'm all Aſtoniſhment!

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p:
Come, Sir, Suſpend your Wonder, Reſpite your Belief ev'n of this, till groſſer Evidence convinces you: Suppoſe I here, before your Face, ſhould let you ſee his Villany, make him repeat his Odious Love to me, at once throw
off his Mask, and ſhew the Barefac'd Traitor.

sp.speaker: Sir J • hn.
sp.p: Is it poſſible? Make me but Witneſs of that Fact, and I ſhall ſoon Accuſe my ſelf, and own my Folly equal to his Baſeneſs: But Pardon me, as I in ſuch a Caſe would not believe, ev'n him Accuſing you, ſo am I bound in equal Charity to think, you yet may be deceiv'd, in what you Charge on him.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: 'Tis Juſt—let it be ſo—we'll yet ſuppoſe him Innocent, till you your ſelf pronounce him Guilty: and ſince I have ſtak'd my Faith upon the Truth of what I urge, 'tis fit we bring him to immediate Tryal: But then Sir, I muſt beg you to deſcend ev'n to the poorShifts we are reduc'd to.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: All, to any thing to eaſe me of my Doubts, propoſe them.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: They that would ſet Toils for Beaſts of Prey, muſt lurk in humble Caves to watch their Haunts.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Place me where you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Under this Table is your only Stand, the Carpet will conceal you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Be it ſo, I'll take my Poſt, what more?

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Mr. Heartly, ſhall we beg your Leave, and you Maria, take the leaſt ſuſpected way to ſend the Doctor to me immediately

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I have a Thought will do it, Madam,—come Sir,

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Here Sir, take this Cuſhion, you will be Eaſier, Sir John goes under the Table.] Now Sir, you muſt conſider how deſperate a Diſeaſe I have undertaken to Cure, therefore you muſt not winch nor ſtir too ſoon, at any freedom you Obſerve me take with him; be ſure lie Cloſe and Still, and when the Proof is full, appear at your Diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Fear not, I'll be Patient.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Huſh! he comes.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Your Woman told me, Madam, you were here alone, and deſir'd to ſpeak with me.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: I did Sir, but that we may be ſure we are alone, pray ſhut the Outward Door, and ſee that Paſſage too be clear, another Surprize might Ruine us—is all ſafe?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I have taken care Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: I am afraid I interrupt your Meditations.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
Say rather you improve them: You, Madam, were the ſubject of my ſolitary Thoughts, I take in all the little aids I can to Guard my Frailty, and truly I have receiv'd
great Conſolation from an Unfortunate Example here before me.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Pray of what kind Sir?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I had juſt dipt into poor Eloiſas Paſſion for Abelard; It is indeed a piteous Conflict! How Terrible! How penitent a Senſe ſhe ſhews of Guilty Pleaſures paſt, and fruitleſs Pains to ſhut them from her Memory.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: I have read her Story, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Is it not pitiful?

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: A Heart of Stone might feel for her.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: O! think then, what I endure for you, ſuch are my Pains; but ſuch is my Sincerity, tho' I fear my being reduc'd to feign a Paſſion for Maria, in my late Surprize, has done diſhonour to the Vows I then preferr'd to You.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: 'Twas on that Point, I wanted now to talk with you, not knowing then, how fat you might miſtake my Silence: Now had I clos'd with the Colonel in Accuſing You, it would have been plain I was your Enemy; as had I joyn'd in your Defence againſt him, it had been as groſsly evident I was his; but ſince I have Uſes for his Friendſhip, and, as I ſaw your Credit with Sir John needed no ſupport, I hope you'll think betwixt the two Extremes I have acted but a prudent Part.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Let me preſume to hope then, what I did, you Judge was Self-Defence, and pure Neceſſity.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: 'Twas wonderful! Surprizing to perfection! The Wit of it—but I won't tell you, what effect it had upon me.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why, Madam? let me beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: No, 'twas nothing—beſide—what need you ask me?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Why do you thus decoy my fooliſh Heart, and feed it, with ſuch Hybla drops of Flattery? You cannot ſure think Kindly of me.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: O well feign'd Fear! You too, I ſind can flatter in your Turn: You know how well the ſubtle force of Modeſty prevails. O Men! Men! Men!

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: 'Twere Arrogance to think I have deſerv'd this Goodneſs: but treat me as you pleaſe, I'll be at leaſt ſincere to you, and frankly own, I ſtill ſuſpect, that all this ſoſrning Favour is but Artifice.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Well! well! I'd have you think ſo.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
What Tranſport would it give, to be aſſur'd I wrong you! but O! I fear this Shaddow of Compliance
is only meant to lure me from Maria, and then as fond Ixions were of old, to fill my Arms with Air.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Methinks this Doubt of me, ſeems rather founded on your ſecond Thoughts of not reſigning Her; 'tis ſhe, I find is your ſubſtantial Happineſs.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: O that you could but fear I thought ſo! how eaſy 'twere to prove my Coldneſs, or my Love.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: O Sir, you have convinc'd me Now of Both.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Can all this pretty Anger then be real? take heed, fair, Creature, it flatters more, than Kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: I can aſſure you Sir, I ſhould have ſpar'd you this trouble, had I known how deeply you were engag'd to her.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Nay then I muſt believe you; but indeed you wrong me, to prove my Innocence, 'tis not an Hour ſince I preſs'd Sir John to give Maria to Young Heartly.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: O! all Artifice! you knew that modeſt reſignation, would make Sir John but warmer in your Intereſt.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Since you will ripe the ſecret from my Heart—know then, I actually have Sold her, like a Bawble, to her Childiſh Lover, for two thouſand times her Value.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Are you ſerious?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: As this is true, or falſe, may I in you be Bleſt, or Miſerable.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: But how can you ſuppoſe Sir John will ever hear of it.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Alas! poor Man! he knows not his own Weakneſs, he's molded into any ſhape, if you but gently ſtroke his Humour: I dare depend on his Conſent—beſide, I intend to Morrow to perſwade him 'tis for the Intereſt of our Cauſe it ſhould be ſo, and then I have him ſure.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Fy! how is that poſſible? he can't be ſo implicitly Credulous, You don't take him ſure for a Roman Catholick.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Um—not abſolutely—But, poor Soul! he little thinks how near he is one. 'Tis true, name to him but Rome, or Popery, he Startles, as at a Monſter: But Gild its groſſeſt Doctrines with the Stile of Engliſh Catholick, he ſwallows down the Poiſon, like a Cordial.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Nay, if he's ſo far within your Power, it cannot fail, He muſt conſent: well Sir, now I give you leave to gueſs the Reaſon, why I too, at our laſt meeting, ſo warmly preſt you to reſign Maria.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Is it poſſible? was I then ſo early your Concern?

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: You cannot blame me ſure, for having there oppos'd your Happineſs.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I dye upon the Tranſport.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Be ſure you are ſecret now: your leaſt Imprudence makes theſe, like Fair favours vaniſh in a Moment.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: How can you form ſo vain a Fear?

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Call it not vain, for let our Converſe end in what it may, you ſtill ſhall find, my Fame is Dear to me, as Life.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Where can it find ſo ſure a guard? the grave Auſterity of my Life will ſtrike Suſpicion Dumb, and yours may mock the Malice of Detraction: I am no Giddy, LooſeLiv'd Courtier, whoſe falſe profeſſion end only his Boaſt of Favours: No, fair ſpotleſs Miracle, the Myſterie of Love are only fit for Hearts Recluſe, and Elevate as mine my Happineſs, like yours, depending on my Secrecy.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: 'Tis you muſt anſwer for this Folly.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I take it whole upon my ſelf, the guilt be only mine, but be our Tranſports Mutual—come lovely Creature, let us withdraw to privacy, where murmuring love ſhall huſh thy Fears, and loſe them in the Burning Joy.

div.stage: [Sir John ſtep • ng ſoftly behind him ſeizes him by the Throat.]

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Traytor!

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Is this thy Sanctity? this thy Doctrine! theſe thy Meditations! If ſtung with my Abuſes I now ſhould Stab thee to the Heart, what Devil durſt murmur 'twere not an Act of Juſtice? But ſince thy Vile Hypocriſy unmask'd, muſt make Mankind Abhor thee, be thy own ſhame, thy living with Puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Do! Triumph Sir—your Artifice has well ſucceeded—I ſee your Ends! you needed not ſo deep a Plot to part with me.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
Suppreſs thy weak evaſions—Ungrateful Wretch! Have I for this redeem'd thee from the Jaws of gaping Poverty, Fed, Cloath'd, Loved, Preferr'd thee to my Boſom, to my Family, and Fortune? Wife, Children, Friends, Servants, all that were not Friends to thee, accounted as my Enemies; nay more to Crown my Faith in thee, I have relied on they Integrity ev'n for my Future Happineſs: And how haſt thou, in one ſhort Day requited me? Taking the Advantage of my Blinded Paſſion, thou haſt turn'd the Duty of my Son to his Undoing; Sordidly haſt Sold the Truſt I made thee of my Daughter,
Attempted, like a Felonious Traytor, to ſeduce my Wife, and haſt I fear, with Poiſonous Doctrines too enſnar'd my Soul.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Now Heav'n be prais'd his Heart ſeems Conſcious of his Error.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But why do I reproach thee? had I not been the weakeſt of Mankind, thou never couldſt have prov'd ſo great a Villain—whether Heaven intends all this to Puniſh, or to Save me, yet I know not; my Senſes ſtaggar at the view, and my Reflexion's loſt in Wild Aſtoniſhment.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: This ſnare was worthy of you, Madam, 'tis you have made this Villain of me.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: You would have made me worſe, but I have only ſhewn him what you were before.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Thank your own Ingratitude, and Wickedneſs: but I muſt now purſue my Victory.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No It ends not here. He was not brought to liſten to this proof alone! There's ſomething deeper yet deſign'd againſt me—I muſt be ſpeedy—ſuppoſe I talk with Charles, allarm him with our Common Danger, Point out his Ruine as our only means of Safety, and like Panther in the Toil provok'd, turn ſhort with Vengeance on my Hunters!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What! ſtill within my Sight! of all my Follys, which is it tells thee, that I now ſhall keep my Temper.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Whom do you menace, me Sir. Reflect upon your own condition firſt, and where you are.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What would the Villain drive at! I prithee leave me, I cannot look on thee! thy overbearing Inſolence confounds me: But ſince thy Wickedneſs has turn'd my Eyes upon my ſelf, and to thy crimes detected, I hope to owe my future Innocence, as the ſore Wound the Viper gives, the Viper beſt can Cure: For that one good may Heaven like me forgive thee: But ſeek thy Biding in ſome other place—out of my Houſe, this inſtant, Hence! be gon! and ſee my ſhameful Face no more.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Nay then, 'tis time to be my ſelf, and let you know, that I am Maſter here, Turn you out Sir, this Houſe is Mine; and now Sir, at your Peril dear to Inſult me.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
O! Heaven! 'tis true, thou haſt diſarm'd my Juſtice, and turn'd its Sword into my own weal Boſom—I had forgot my Folly, 'tis fit it ſhould be ſo, and Heaven is
Juſt, at once to let me ſee my Crime, and Puniſhment—O my poor Injur'd Son!—Whither ſhall I fly to hide me from the World?

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: Whither are you going Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I know not—but here it ſeems I am a Treſpaſſer—the Maſter of this Houſe has warn'd me hence, and ſince the Right is now in him, 'tis Juſt I ſhould reſign it.

sp.speaker: Lady W.
sp.p: You ſhall not ſtir: he dares not Act with ſuch abandon'd Inſolence, No Sir, Poſſeſſion ſtill is yours, if he pretends a Right, let him by open Courſe of Law maintain it.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Are theſe the ſhifts you are reduc'd to? no Madam, I ſhall not wait ſo ſlow a Vengeance, you'll find I have a ſhorter way to Rout you.—here! Charles!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nay then there is an end of all—I have provok'd a Serpent—my Life, I ſee, muſt Pay the Forfeit of my Folly!

sp.speaker: Lady W.
